69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:30): server

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:36): GET requests work like now but without credentials, and if the server replies with an Access-Include-Credentials they are redone with credentials
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:37): can the user be prompted in the initial request?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:37): in case of http auth

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:47): guess so

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:48): i don't think we should ever prompt the user for credentials in any request that will be subject to Access-Control management
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:50): so you'd just get a 403 back (or 401?) and be done with it?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:50): i guess that's ok
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:52): (that is of course, if the server actually provides Access-Control headers with the 401)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:55): that way the third party host knows to tell the user to log in
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:56): the way the spec is written now all status codes work cross-site
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:56): i hope browsers implement that too as I think it's useful
